text: all right that makes us time so um my name is Nick Randolph um I currently run a consulting company called build Drome
here in Sydney but I'm also part of the Uno platform core team and that's part of the session today is we're going to
talk about the Uno platform um but more importantly we're going to talk about the the the components that we have for
working with figma and taking design through the code um to try and improve that process of you know building apps
um so just to gauge people's experience here how many people have heard of the Uno platform okay I'll give you a quick
background of what we are and what we do uh how many people have spent some time in figma ah more people okay you probably
spend more time in figer than I have collectively um so if I run into issues I'll call on the collective knowledge
here to to get me out of strife um so what is the Uno platform so the Uno
platform is a cross-platform technology um so it's you know it's a app
development technology um fundamentally at the core so if you've heard of Maui it's kind of like an equivalent of that
is in the net space um but we target all of the platforms so we do web so wasm uh
we do mobile we do desktop um you know we do embedded if you want to go that direction um but the idea is that you
can take a single set of source code and build an app for all of these different platforms you can build it on any OS so
if you happen to be working on Mac you can build it using what was vs for Mac um but now obviously vs code you're
working on Linux got support there as well um and then you can pick from your choice choice of IDE so we've got
components that built into Visual Studio vs code um and work with ryer as well um
but beyond that the reason why Uno is called the Uno platform is that it's not just about the core technology we also
have building blocks that set on top of that because we recognize that the process of building apps is more than just cutting code it's taking designs
all the way through to publishing your application so the idea is that we're now building abstractions and and layers
that sit on top of that to help you you know get through that app development process as quickly as possible while
still maintaining high quality applications um so on the right hand side got options in terms of what markup
technology you want to use so if you want to stick in zaml because that's where the heritage of sort of Windows developments come kind of come from you
can do that if you prefer to stay in cop then you can do that as well got a couple of different Technologies in
terms of State Management so if you've built apps before you'll you'll be familiar with you know the you know how
you track state in terms of each page you know the content that's on the page you know the data that's within your
application and how that flows through back to the server um so a couple of different Technologies there and then on
top of all of this we then have a bunch of modules and components that you can then use to actually build out your
application so you know we have a a toolkit that has a number of additional components that make it that optimize
things for mobile uh we have a number of extensions so if you've worked with the Microsoft extensions you know if you
build service side components you'll be familiar with you know the Microsoft extensions for logging dependency injection those types of things we have
those for the Uno platform as well um and then in the design side of things we have um Uno themes and the idea there is
that you can reskin your application whether you choose to use the material design language fluent um or catino you
can basically pick from your choice of design system to actually apply that to your application so the idea is it's
designed to be modular um and the end of the day if you have your own technology like so we're working in net right so if
you have your own library that you want to bring go for it it'll work um and so you can bring in whatever you want to do
okay we have a number of of customers across a range of Technologies and and different um Industries um and so this
kind of gives us the grounding to talk about design and and to come from it with an element of experience in terms
of okay we've been through this process with a number of applications and so we know you know what designers are
expecting we know what developers are expecting and the two very very very rarely are the same okay um and this
goes down to the way that actually designers think about things and the way and the tooling um and if you spend some
time in figu you'll know that you know Auto layout Works a certain way and then if you come from the developer space
you'll know that things like zaml and stuff like that work a different way and the two don't necessarily see eye to eye
and so that's half the challenge here is that when you get an export out of figmo and you put it into zaml all of a sudden
you know a margin in zaml is actually the reverse of what you know the way the padding and stuff like that works in
figma right so that's that becomes a bit of a challenge particularly where developers go I know this stuff inside
out dropping them into Figo and they all of a sudden go okay I'm not sure what the design what the designer was
actually thinking here and so that's part of the challenge is that we have this handoff problem between designers
and developers and quite often it's a massive Chasm it's a matter of designer finishes the design they send an email
with an attached PDF and goes here's design please Implement and the developer goes okay that looks fine I'm
going to I'm going to go ahead and do that and all of a sudden they end up with something that doesn't scale properly um or doesn't you know have the
right components the right font size those sorts of things so this massive handoff problem where designers don't
provide necessarily what the developers are expecting and it's not because the two are any better or worse at their
jobs they're just different and so you know designers have a focus area of making sure that things are pixel
perfect that things are aligned developers have a process where they make sure that things are functionally correct in terms of is it the right data
on the screen um and the two very rarely are the same okay developers very rarely
think okay well that margin's important to make sure that everything's align um whereas a designer will come to it and
go that's not right that's not what I specified and so if we can put Tooling in the place to actually alleviate that
problem then we're one step closer to having a success and eliminating that sort of Chasm on the other end the
Spectrum we actually have a number of tools like the power power apps and things like that that are very prescriptive in terms of the way the
Design's done so they they kind of limit the amount of design and creativity that you can do in order to make sure that we
can ship applications really quickly okay um and so we're trying to get away from that end of the spectrum as well
and so the idea there is that we have the sort of components of technology that sit in the middle that help that
Handover process and what's really interesting is if you look at the figma space over the last year or so there's
an increased Focus to actually support this mode this handoff and so we've seen seen things like Dev mode appear um
we're seeing a number of Design Systems that actually have you know pre-built libraries coming from you know Google
and Microsoft and even Apple's got one now in terms of their um human interaction design um and so they
recognize that this is a problem they recognize that the way to deal with it is to have these Design Systems implemented in figma to not only help
design as you know jump start there at you know design but also to hand help
that Handover process to developers uh so in the Unos poost we
have we essentially have two components or two parts to the figma support we have a component library and at the
moment that's limited to material so it's a material toolkit um and then we have a plugin that sits into figma and
the plugin there is actually an Uno app and I'll show you that as we go through the demo uh it's a it's a wasm component
that basically sits in inside figma but allows us to do some fairly creative things in terms of previewing what your
design would look like like as a running application without you having to leave leave figma so there's some quite
interesting things there and then because we can essentially we're exporting what's in figma into the
running app we can then give you the zaml or the C markup that you can then take and actually drop it into your code
um and so we'll see that as part of the demo um and we've got support for various parts of the Uno Uno platform
that I spoke about so things like um support for navigation extensions and reactive and stuff like that um all from
within bigma okay the idea here is that we're
basically trying to accelerate two parts here so on the on the left hand side we we've got this material toolkit um the
idea there is it's hopefully a faithful representation of the material design language um and I say hopefully because
material keeps on changing what they mean and adding things and and so you know there's an ongoing process of
making sure that our component toolkit is updated to the latest support for material um but the idea there is that
there are components and templates that you can then take and actually as part of your design you can rapidly pull
those together uh to basically reduce the amount of time that you spend actually coming out with design because
the last thing you want to do when you're starting out building an app and go I need to recreate a button in figma and it's like well hang on we've done
this a thousand times before there are versions of that fluent material and catino why can't I just drag those in
and start using them in my application and and the idea there is that you can so we're looking at cutting down the
amount of time we're spending on design but then also the the amount of time that in development we're spending actually doing the UI now in all of the
apps that I've spent building time building the UI is fundamentally the hardest part of building front end
applications I don't care what people tell you about oh offline support oh connecting to services and stuff like
that nothing compares to the pixel pushing that goes into actually making sure an app works particularly if it's
crossplatform um and and things have come a long way in the last five years um when we first
started down this road when sort of zamarin was a was a a new beast in the net space um things were really hard but
you know with zamarin forms Maui and now Uno platform we're now getting to a state where that get that's that process
is getting a lot smoother okay so I I spoke about these two components um so the Uno platform
material toolkit is essentially the coming together of the Uno platform with a material toolkit for figma um and I
say it that way because there are a number of other material toolkits that are available for figma so you know I
think well Google's got one and then there are other people who have come come into figma and gone okay well we've
got this material design language um we're going to implement it in figma um come up with components and and colors
and themes and all of that stuff within figma that we can then use to basically jump start our designs so Uno platform
has a version of that it's called our material toolkit um and it's specifically designed so that we can export to the Uno platform okay so we
have components in there that will be familiar if you're used to you know working in with material and so the
naming of colors and brushes and stuff like that will be very familiar but if you're also familiar with the Uno
platform so from a developer perspective you'll see things like oh it's a text box okay well that makes sense because
that aligns to what I'm expecting to see in terms of my application so the idea there is that it's the coming together
of these two things and it's and this being brings us to the first point there which is about consistency as and
efficiency so the designers are talking about the same components because we have a a standard toolkit they're
pulling in a text box and that text box translates exactly to what the developers are expecting the other end
okay and there's a number of other components that that translate like that um it is about cross disciplinary
collaboration so the idea there is that we we're all talking a common design language as such and so you know
developers will open up the figma file they use the plugin to basically grab the zaml and the C markup and actually
drop it into their application um okay uh it is a free resource um and yes it's a it's a great
starting point for building out your application um it is as I mentioned a
faithful representation of the material 3 um design language um it does evolve
over time so there are new versions of the of the material toolkit that we do publish it's available on the in the

translate correctly um has a bunch of Tex Styles hundreds of icons and you'll
see this there's literally pages of them um the idea there is that you shouldn't have to go hunting for icons you can

happens to be built as a a wasm application using the Uno platform um and we do this for a number of reasons
um not the least of which is so that we can do this live preview and so essentially what's happening is that we're taking your figma design we're
extracting it as zaml um and then we're actually you know launching it into the figma plugin um and actually showing you
a live representation of what your application will look like so you can be pretty certain that you know at least in
the web version of it it'll look exactly like you're seeing actually in pigma uh
does support cop mark up andl um cop mark a relatively new thing um and the idea between uh with the Uno platforms C
markup is that it aligns pretty closely with what you'd expect if you come from the zaml world okay so the layout there
it is designed to be a very declarative um way of representing your application
so it's not a um you know a a create new text block you know add it to the grid
that type of thing it's basically a very fluent representation of that um but the idea is that the figma plug-in can
export those um there's various documentation uh one click to export which you see in the demo um it does
make heavily use of Auto layout so if you're used to figma and the auto layout capability there um what it will
actually generated is we have an auto layout component that that exists in the Uno World um and so rather than using
grids and stack panels we actually use an auto layout um and that means that we have very close alignment with the what
we're expecting out of um out of figma uh it is Dev mode ready so basically if
you're using Dev mode the figma plugin will actually appear in the the dev mode if you're not using Dev mode it'll just
appear as a regular plugin um and then there is support for vs code as well
